```{python}
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

hearingcleaned = pd.read_csv("hearing_cleaned.csv")

pd.set_option("display.max_rows", None) #show all rows
pd.set_option("display.max_columns", None) #show all columns
pd.set_option("display.max_colwidth", None) #make columns wide enough

hearingcleaned.describe(include='all').transpose()
#transposed to see all the columns as rows
```

```{python}
fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(12, 5))

yesmaybeno_order = ["Yes", "Maybe", "No"] #to fix order for yes, maybe & no
yesmaybeno_colours = ["green", "steelblue", "red"]

app_interest = (
    hearingcleaned['Interest_in_Hearing_App_clean']
    .value_counts()
    .reindex(yesmaybeno_order)
)
#shown this way because code is too long
paidapp_interest = (
    hearingcleaned['Paid_App_Test_Interest_clean']
    .value_counts()
    .reindex(yesmaybeno_order)
)

ax1.bar(app_interest.index, app_interest.values, color=yesnomaybe_colours)
ax1.set_title('Interest in a Hearing Health App', fontsize=10)
ax1.set_xlabel('Interest Level', fontsize=10)
ax1.set_ylabel('Number of Respondents', fontsize=10)

ax2.bar(paidapp_interest.index, paidapp_interest.values, color=yesnomaybe_colours)
ax2.set_title('Interest in a paid Hearing Health App', fontsize=10)
ax2.set_xlabel('Interest Level', fontsize=10)
ax2.set_ylabel('Number of Respondents', fontsize=10)
ax2.yaxis.set_label_position("right")

plt.show()


```
